headline: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Visa Fee Sets Off Scramble Across Corporate America
summary: Companies have urgently ordered workers back to the U.S. before Sunday. The White House is seeking to calm the situation, noting the fee doesn’t apply to current visa holders.

raw.headline: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Visa Fee Sets Off Scramble Across Corporate America
raw.summary: Companies have urgently ordered workers back to the U.S. before Sunday. The White House is seeking to calm the situation, noting the fee doesn’t apply to current visa holders.

headline: This Tech Wiz Sold His Company For $1.6 Billion – Then Gave It All Away Because He Thinks Owning Super Yachts Is 'Obnoxious'
summary: Imagine founding a tech company, selling it for $1.6 billion, and then giving all but $100 million of it to your favorite charities. It sounds far-fetched, but that's exactly what AppNexus founder Brian O’Kelly has been doing since he sold his company in 2018. O'Kelly told Fortune that his philanthropy is rooted in his sense of personal responsibility and commitment to living a normal life. headline: Modi urges Indians to get rid of foreign products
summary: STORY: :: India's Modi asks citizens to stop using foreign-made products and instead to buy local:: September 21, 2025:: Narendra Modi, Indian Prime Minister"We are using many foreign goods in our day-to-day life, knowingly or unknowingly. We don't even know if the comb in our pocket is locally-made or foreign-made, we don't know. We also have to get rid of it. We will buy goods that are made in India."After U.S. President Donald Trump imposed a 50% tariff on imported Indian goods, Modi has been urging use of "Swadeshi", or made-in-India goods. His supporters have started campaigns to boycott American brands including McDonald's, Pepsi and Apple, which are hugely popular in India.India's population of 1.4 billion is a major market for American consumer goods, often purchased from U.S. online retailer Amazon.com. Over the years, the reach of U.S. brands has expanded deep into smaller towns.

headline: Is Amazon Prime Too Hard to Cancel? A Jury Will Decide.
summary: The Federal Trade Commission is set to scrutinize Amazon’s cash cow, the Prime subscription service, in a civil trial in Seattle, including tactics the FTC says get consumers to sign up and keep them from canceling.
